Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
The agency failed to provide services to the family. The case was assigned to the
agency on November 27, 2019. A referral for services was only completed on May
1, 2020.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator via telephone on
May 12, 2020. He reported being present at a home visit with Foster Children 1’s birth
parents on December 10, 2019. He stated he offered the birth parents services during
the home visit, however, they said no to the service referrals because their attorney
advised them to not participate as it may not be in their favor since the case had not
been adjudicated. The Chief Administrator stated a Family Team Meeting (FTM) was
held in April 2020 and that is when the birth parents asked for services. He said in April
2020, the agency had difficulty finding service providers for the birth parents due to
COVID-19.
I interviewed Ingham County MDHHS Foster Care POS Monitor via telephone on June
16, 2020. She said in the beginning of March 2020 she received an email from Foster
Children 1’s relative caregiver indicating the children have been out of the parental
home since Thanksgiving and no services have been provided to the birth parents.
Ingham County MDHHS Foster Care POS Monitor stated she contacted Ennis Center
for Children-Pontiac regarding services not being provided to the birth parents. The
agency provided various reasons for services not being provided. She said initially the
agency said the birth parents refused services. Then the agency informed her that CPS
is supposed to refer the birth parents for services and since the case was not yet
adjudicated, they could not provide services. She reported the agency also said
services could not be provided because everything had been shut down due to COVID-
19. Ingham County MDHHS Foster Care POS Monitor stated the agency never
contacted her regarding how services for the birth parents would be paid for since the
case had not been adjudicated nor did they communicate to her that they could not find
service providers due to COVID-19. She stated the foster children have returned to the
parental home with Family Reunification Program (FRP) services.
I interviewed Birth Mother A via telephone on June 16, 2020. Birth Mother A stated in
the very beginning she and the birth father refused to participate in services because
their attorney told them that it would not help their case if they participated in services
since the case had not been adjudicated. She reported in February 2020, they decided
that it would be best to participate in services and they asked Ennis Center for Children-
Pontiac Foster Care Worker A to refer them to services. Birth Mother A said Ennis
Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A stated MDHHS had to pay for the
services because MDHHS had jurisdiction of the case. She reported services were still
not in place in April 2020, so she asked the agency again about the services. She
stated FRP services and substance abuse services were put in place in May 2020.
3

I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Supervisor A via telephone
on June 16, 2020. She stated services were offered to the birth parents within 30 days
of Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac accepting case responsibility. However, the birth
parents refused to participate in services because they said their attorney told them that
by participating in services shows that they are admitting guilt. She said the birth
parents refused to participate in services until mid-April 2020. Ennis Center for
Children-Pontiac Foster Care Supervisor A reported the birth parents agreed to
participate in services during the April 2020 FTM. She reported the agency had issues
with finding service providers due to COVID-19. She stated the birth parents were given
online resources for parenting classes and FRP services were put in the home once the
foster children were returned home. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care
Supervisor A reported approximately a couple of weeks before the April 2020 FTM she
discussed with Ingham County MDHHS Foster Care POS Monitor that MDHHS would
pay for services prior to the case being adjudicated.
I reviewed Foster Children 1's case in MiSACWIS on June 16, 2020 and June 18, 2020.
MiSACWIS documented the following:
 Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac accepted Foster Children 1’s case on
November 27, 2019.
 The Initial Service Plan (ISP) report period was from November 27, 2019 to
December 26, 2019. The ISP stated, “The children and parents have been
offered foster care case management and visitation. This case has not been
adjudicated; however, the parents were offered to start services voluntarily but
refused. The parents refuse to participate until the court orders them.”
 The Updated Service Plan (USP) report period was from December 27, 2019 to
March 25, 2020. A face-to-face social work contact with the birth parents and
Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A dated January 21, 2020
stated the birth parents were given a copy of the PATP. They were asked to read
over the PATP and sign it at the end, acknowledging that they read, agree, or
disagree and received a copy. The birth parents both refused to sign the PATP,
stating that they did not agree with what was being stated and they wanted to
speak with their attorney first.
 Foster Children 1’s birth parents signed the ISP Parent Agency Treatment Plan
(PATP) on January 21, 2020 and wrote, “Refuse to sign until we speak to
lawyer.” Foster Children 1’s birth parents signed the USP PATP on April 23,
2020.
 A FTM was completed on March 5, 2020. The birth parents attended the FTM but
did not sign the FTM activity report. The FTM activity report indicated the birth
parents report being willing to do whatever they can to get their children back
home. It also stated the birth parents have reported they do not have the
financial means to go out and pay for services on their own.
 A FTM was completed on April 14, 2020. The birth parents attended the FTM.
The FTM activity report indicated the birth parents have not participated in any
services. It stated the birth parents are willing to participate in services. Ennis
Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A is to provide birth parents with
4

referrals and resources for parenting time and anger management. It stated that
there is a possibility of returning the children home with FRP services.
 Foster Children 1 were returned to the birth parents’ home on May 22, 2020 with
FRP services.
I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A via telephone on
June 18, 2020. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A stated during
the ISP report period, the Chief Administrator offered the birth parents service referrals
at an initial home visit with the birth parents, however, the birth parents said that their
attorney instructed them not to participate in services as it would admit guilt. She stated
during the first USP report period, the birth parents still refused to participate in services
voluntarily because they could not afford them. She stated all MDHHS counties are
different when it comes to paying for services and she was unaware that Ingham
County MDHHS would pay for services prior to the case being adjudicated. Ennis
Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A reported that she does not recall one
way or the other if the birth parents requested to participate in services in February
2020. She stated that once the birth parents agreed to complete services COVID-19
occurred and it was difficult to find providers to service the birth parents. She stated she
did not ask Ingham County MDHHS Foster Care POS Monitor for assistance in
obtaining services to the birth parents as she thought that every county handled
payment of services the same not knowing that Ingham County MDHHS would pay for
the services.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be
primarily responsible for the development, implementation,
and review of service plans for the children and their
families.
MDHHS Policy Service Referrals.
FOM 722-06
Front Loading Services
Front loading services is an essential component of
concurrent permanency planning that includes immediate
referrals for needed services at the beginning of a case; see
FOM 722-07A, Concurrent Permanency Planning. The
assigned caseworker must make appropriate service
5

referrals for the family, as soon as possible, but no later
than 30 calendar days after entry into care.
If the service provider is unable to immediately provide the
service, the caseworker must document in the case service
plan that the service is unavailable and identify the date
that the service will become available.
If the service is unavailable for more than 30 calendar days,
the caseworker must determine if other service providers
offer the same or similar service and make a referral. If it is
determined that there is no secondary service provider
available, the caseworker must locate alternate service
providers and document these efforts in the case service
plan.
ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to show that Ennis Center for
Children-Pontiac failed to provide Foster Children 1’s birth
parents service referrals no later than 30 calendar days after
entry into care. The ISP, the ISP PATP and Birth Mother A’s
account indicate that the birth parents refused to participate in
services stating that their attorney advised them not to
participate until the court adjudicated the case.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
During a review of MiSACWIS, it was determined that a FTM for the ISP was not
completed.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A via telephone on
June 18, 2020. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Worker A stated during
the ISP report period she was attending Child Welfare Training Institute and does not
know if a FTM was completed for the ISP report period.
APPLICABLE RULE
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home
cases:
• Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
6

Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case
Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every
FTM.
ANALYSIS: A FTM for the ISP was not documented in MiSACWIS as being
completed. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care
Worker A stated during the ISP report period she was attending
Child Welfare Training Institute and does not know if a FTM was
completed for the ISP report period.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend the agency’s
regular license status continue.
